summary: Block Access to North Korea Act of 2016 or BANK Act of 2016 This bill requires the President to impose sanctions pursuant to the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, with specified waiver authority, against a person that continues to knowingly and directly provide specialized financial messaging services to, or to knowingly enable or facilitate access to such messaging services for:   the Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea),  a financial institution that facilitates any transaction or provides significant financial services for nuclear development or proliferation on North Korea's behalf, or  a person identified on the list of specially designated nationals and blocked persons maintained by the Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control for assisting North Korea's nuclear development or proliferation efforts.
predicted_summary: North Korea continues to develop a ballistic missile and nuclear weapons program, despite numerous united states and international sanctions, including United Nations Security Council resolutions against North Korea and North Korea, and continued investments in its nuclear program.Directs the United States to ensure that all financial institutions in the region are held accountable for their compliance with applicable laws and regulations regarding financial institutions.Authorizes the President to impose sanctions with respect to: (1) continuing to knowingly and directly provide specialized financial messaging services to the central bank of the democratic people's republic of Korea and certain other financial institutions and sanctioned persons; and (2) continued use of such services by such financial institutions or sanctioned persons.Directs the President to waive the requirement to impose sanctions with respect to a person under this Act if: (1) the person is subject to a sanctions regime under its governing foreign law that requires it to eliminate the knowing provision of such messaging services, and the knowing enabling and facilitation of direct or indirect access to such services for, the central bank of the democratic people's republic of Korea, any financial institution described in subsection (2) and any person described in subparagraph (A) in the form of a waiver from the U.S. sanctioning authority; and (2 (3) the President determines that this waiver is in the national interest of the United States and does not conflict with the policy of the President.Directs a person to: (1) use such messaging services to transfer money to or from other financial institutions; and (2) make such transactions available to the recipient of such money.

summary: Social Security Protection Act of 2011 - Makes it out of order in the Senate or the House of Representatives to consider any legislation that: (1) increases the retirement age or the early retirement age for individuals receiving benefits under title II (Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act on or after the enactment of this Act; (2) reduces cost-of-living increases for them; (3) reduces benefit payment amounts for them; or (4) creates private retirement accounts for any of the OSADI benefits they receive.
predicted_summary: Social Security Act of 2009 - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide Social Security benefits to: (1) retirees and their spouses; and (2) disabled individuals and spouses, with the exception of a spouse or parent whose death has affected their ability to work or to make ends meet; (3) beneficiaries of Social Security programs are eligible for Medicare, Medicaid, and other federal matching funds.Social Security Benefit Guarantee Act - Establishes the Social Security Trust Fund, a set of trust funds established by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) to provide Social Security benefits to every recipient until 2037, with enough funding remaining after that date to pay about 78 percent of benefits.Social Security Disability Insurance Program (SDSIP) - Establishes a program to provide Social Security benefits for retirees and disabled individuals.Requires the Senate and the House of Representatives to consider, for purposes of the old-age, survivors, and disability insurance benefit program established under title ii of the Social Security Act (SSA), any legislation that increases the retirement age (as defined in section 401 et seq. ) or increases the contribution age for such program.Amends the Social Security Act to:  (1) reduce benefit payment amounts for individuals receiving benefits under title ii of the Act; (2) reduce the benefit payment amount for individuals with pre-retirement age eligibility (EVET) eligibility for Social Security benefits; and (3) allow individuals with advanced age savings accounts (ERAs) to opt out of the early retirement age.Authorizes the Speaker of the House of Representatives to suspend the application of this Act.

summary: Gold King Mine Spill Accountability Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of Justice (DOJ) to appoint a special investigator to investigate: (1) who was at fault for the discharge of contaminated water from the Gold King Mine north of Silverton, Colorado, into Cement Creek; (2) which individuals were responsible for the decisions that led to the spill; and (3) what downstream environmental effects were caused by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) actions, or inactions, after the spill.  The bill: (1) entitles individuals to receive compensation for a claim filed, or civil action brought, under the Federal Tort Claims Act relating to an injury resulting from the spill, and (2) establishes within the EPA the Office of Gold King Mine Spill Claims for processing claims of allowable damages resulting from the spill. The EPA may provide compensation for a claim in an amount greater than $25,000 without the prior approval of DOJ. The EPA must fund the implementation of the long-term monitoring program developed by the Long-Term Impact Review Team of New Mexico, for the water quality of the Animas and San Juan Rivers. The EPA may not finalize or work on any rules (including those not related to the spill) until all claims have been paid, except rules that are necessary to address an imminent threat to public health or safety, or other emergency.
predicted_summary: Requires the Attorney General to appoint a special investigator to investigate the environmental impact of the spill.The Special Investigator may issue subpoenas requiring the attendance and testimony of Federal employees.Sets forth procedures for the issuance of subpoenas. Authorizes the Special Investigator to: (1) apply to a united States district court for an order requiring that person to appear before the Special investigator to give testimony, produce evidence, or both, relating to the matter under investigation; and (2) make an application within the judicial district where the hearing is conducted or where that person is found, resides, or transacts business.Directs the Comptroller General to report to Congress on the results of an audit of an investigation to determine whether: (1) the investigator had any conflict of interest relating to the subject matter of the investigation or with the environmental protection agency; and (2) the findings are based on substantiated scientific evidence.Requires the Special Investigator to report to Congress on the status of the Animas and San Juan River Watersheds downstream of the gold king mine.Requires the Administrator to provide compensation for a claim in an amount greater than $25,000 without prior written approval of the Attorney General (or a designee), upon request of the head of any federal department or agency, on a reimbursable basis, any personnel who may assist in carrying out this Act.Prohibits punitive damages for loss of property from the spill except for compensations for lost use for traditional or ceremonial uses, conducted on tribal or non-federal land damaged by the spill, or from water damaged.Gold King Mine Safety Act - Amends the Internal Revenue Code to require the Attorney General to file a financial loss notice with the Secretary of Commerce and with the SEC, after 10 calendar years, for each $1,000 in unreimbursed damages.Directs the Attorney General to file civil and criminal charges against the federal officer, employee, contractor, or subcontractor under specified circumstances in which the claimant would be liable to the claimant.Requires the Administrator to make finalizing a rule or engaging in a rule making until all claims processed under this Act have been paid in full.Gold King Mine Environmental Pollution Control Act - Directs the Secretary of the Environmental Protection Agency (EDP) to investigate and report on the contamination of water from the Gold King mine.

summary:
Rural Broadband Access Enhancement Act - Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to redefine "eligible rural community."

Permits a loan or loan guarantee applicant in an area where 40% of the residents are without broadband access to qualify with a 10% loan equity position.

Provides for: (1) paperwork reduction; and (2) program outreach to underserved areas.

Prohibits loan or loan guarantees for new broadband service in communities with three or more service providers.

Provides that for each fiscal year: (1) not more than 10% of program funds shall be available to providers with more than 10% of national subscriber lines; and (2) 40% of program funds shall be available to providers with between 2%-10% of national subscriber lines.

Revises the amortization period from the life of the asset to 35 years.

Requires an annual broadband program report to Congress.
predicted_summary: Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to: (1) make eligible rural communities in the urbanized area contiguous and adjacent to such a city, town, or village eligible for electrification; and (2) require the rural community to have at least 20% of the median household income of the residents of such a community.Sets forth equity requirements for applications submitted to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) in areas in which at least 40 percent of the population does not have access to broadband service, unless the value of the assets of the applicant not pledged or hypothecated for any other purpose is more than $1 million.Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to: (1) require the securitization of certain transmission lines in rural areas to be made available for the provision of new broadband service to 3 or more rural communities; and (2) require certain amounts of such transmission line ownership to be available for entities with various shares of installed telephone subscriber lines.Amends the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Act to extend the useful life of certain rural electrification assets acquired with the proceeds of the loan or extension of credit to "35 years".Directs the Secretary to: (1) report to Congress on the status of the program; and (2) make available to the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry of the House and the Senate a report on the program status.

summary:
Wounded Warrior Transition Assistance Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of each military department to provide each reserve member of that department who is being evaluated for separation or retirement for disability, or for placement on the temporary disability retired list or inactive status list, the option to remain on active duty during such evaluation in order to continue to receive military pay and allowances, until the member is: (1) cleared to return to duty; or (2) separated, retired, or placed on the temporary disability retired or inactive status list.

Requires each Secretary to retain on active duty (for pay and allowances purposes) a reserve member who incurs an injury or illness while on active duty, is being discharged or separated from the Armed Forces, or is being released from active duty, and is not being evaluated in connection with such discharge, separation, or release, until the member is: (1) retired or placed on the temporary disability retired or inactive status list; or (2) determined ineligible for such care or benefits based solely upon the injury or illness.

Requires military human resources commands to return to active duty during their evaluation period reserve members who request such option.

Encourages the use of local residences by reserve members during such transition periods.

Authorizes the use of Defense Health Program funds for reserve members who become ill or injured while on active duty and separate as a result of such illness or injury.

Provides for the assignment of Judge Advocate General personnel to assist members of the Armed Forces (members) in connection with the medical discharge process and disability evaluations.

Expresses support for access of veterans service organizations to military facilities to provide counseling and services to members.
predicted_summary: Requires the Secretary of the Army to give a member of a reserve component who is being evaluated for separation or retirement for disability the option to remain on active duty in order to continue to receive pay and allowances under this Act.Requires the Secretary of the Army to retain on active duty a member of a reserve component of the Armed Forces who incurs an injury or illness while on duty, or is being released from active duty in order for the member to continue to receive pay and allowances until such time as the member has been discharged or separated from the unit.Authorizes the Human Resources Command to return a member of a reserve component to active duty if: (1) each member is determined by an appropriate physician (including a private physician) to be disabled, placed on the temporary disability retired list, or receiving health care and disability benefits through the Department of Veterans Affairs; and (2) each such member is discharged from the active-duty military or the reserve component after 30 days after the discharge.Sets forth requirements for: (1) the receipt of a medical evaluation; and (2) use of local residences for reserve component members.Requires a member of a reserve component to: (1) be permitted to reside at the member's permanent place of residence if medically feasible, as determined by a licensed health care provider; and (2) a member returned to active duty for a specified period of time, to be reimbursed for expenses incurred by the member.Military Personnel Support Act of 2003 - Directs the Secretary of Defense to ensure that the number of members of the judge advocate general's corps under the jurisdiction of such a military department are dedicated to providing legal assistance to armed forces members who are serving time in the armed forces.Requires the Secretary of Defense to provide appropriate assistance on all legal matters relating to medical discharge from the Armed Forces.Requires the Secretary to ensure that the judge advocate general's corps under the jurisdiction of the Secretary has the capacity to provide legal assistance to members of the armed force or armed forces who are undergoing disability evaluation in connection with such evaluation.Requires that: (1) each commander of a military installation be given the authority to ensure the use of space and equipment at military installations; and (2) each member of the Judge Advocate General's Corps to practice before the Department of Veterans Affairs in connection with representation of members of the Armed Forces undergoing disability evaluation.Directs the Secretary of Defense to: (1) distribute information regarding the existence and availability of the wounded warrior resource center to members of the Armed Forces and their dependents; (2) establish a medical evaluation referral system for such individuals; and (3) ensure that such centers are accessible to all military personnel, including non-combatants, serving in the armed forces, or serving in other armed forces.Directs the Department of Defense to provide $50,000,000 ($150,000 for each hour of recovery time) for erroneous payments to contractors pursuant to recovery audits and activities carried out by the Department.
